results.title: Memory lingers on
results.creator_credit: Colleen Johnson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Whether its in the eyes of her grandchild or the photos and memories of those loved and lost, Colleen Johnson feels a deep connection to her family. No matter what, they are her heart and soul.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Colleen Johnson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.creator_credit: Ceciline Biles, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Coming home
results.creator_credit: Christina Brims, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Christina Brim’s mum died recently and a lot of memories and stories have been going around in my head. Brims pays tribute to her mother, the glue that kept her ‘large mob’ together and cohesive.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Christina Brims, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Barkindji memories
results.creator_credit: Simone Spencer, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Simone Spencer shares the happy memories that filled her childhood. Her large family, her close friends and her time at school all contributed to the happy person she is today. It is also why she wants to help others.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Simone Spencer, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Ada's story
results.creator_credit: Ada Peterson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Ada Peterson’s brother received a call twelve years ago from a person they didn’t know. It was their sister, Rhonda, who was taken as a child, a member of what is now known as the stolen generation. After getting over the initial shock and apprehension, getting to know Rhonda and her story has taken Ada’s life in a different direction, bringing her closer to celebrating who she is.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ada Peterson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Ka Rorn: southern village
results.creator_credit: Arch Nicholson, Thanom Soongnarata, John Morris and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our Asian Neighbours: Thailand”.
At 3am the village of Ka Rorn comes to life and work begins. Produce must be taken to market in Phuket, the only major town on the island. Ka Rorn is a tight, relaxed, self-sufficient community of about 30 families. The people grow coconuts and fruit to sell in the market but, being an island village, fishing is the most lucrative industry.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Arch Nicholson, Thanom Soongnarata, John Morris and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Chiang Mai: northern capital
results.creator_credit: Brian Hannant, Thanom Soongnarata, John Morris and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our Asian Neighbours: Thailand”.
In Chiang Mai, Thailand’s northern capital, many traditions and crafts have remained unchanged for hundreds of years. This film looks at the native handicrafts, including the production of silver jewellery, lacquerware utensils and silk-weaving. We take part in a colourful festival which marks the end of the Buddhist Lent. Through the day and into the night we see the solemn religious ceremonies, and the carefree carnival, complete with fireworks
results.creator_credit_for_label: Brian Hannant, Thanom Soongnarata, John Morris and Australian National Film Board

results.title: Temple of twenty pagodas
results.creator_credit: Brian Hannant, John Morris and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our Asian Neighbours: Thailand”.
In Northern Island is a monastery said to be two thousand years old. It is called “Wa Chedi Sao”, which in Northern Thai means the Temple of Twenty Pagodas. This film is about the daily life of the monastery and the village which it serves.
